{{Expand French|Énergie solaire en France|date=March 2016|topic=}} [[File:SolarGIS-Solar-map-France-en.png|thumb|upright=1.35|[[Insolation]] map]] '''Solar power in France''' including overseas territories reached an installed capacity figure of 9,466 MW by the end of 2018 generating 10,196 GWh of power. The solar power capacity is set to continue expanding with a target of around 18–20 GW installed by 2023.{{Cite web|url=http://www.developpement-durable.gouv.fr/Programmation-pluriannuelle-de-l,48569.html|title=Ministre de l'Environnement, de l'Énergie et de la Mer, Programmation pluriannuelle de l’énergie, 27 October 2016.|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}} However, wavering political support for new installations slowed PV deployment since the record year of 2011, when 1,700 MW had been installed. In January 2016, the President of France, [[François Hollande]], and the Prime Minister of India, [[Narendra Modi]], laid the foundation stone for the headquarters of the [[Sunshine countries|International Solar Alliance]] (ISA) in Gwalpahari, Gurgaon, India. The ISA will focus on promoting and developing solar energy and solar products for countries lying wholly or partially between the [[Tropic of Cancer]] and the [[Tropic of Capricorn]]. The alliance of over 120 countries was announced at the Paris COP21 climate summit.{{Cite news|url=http://www.alternet.org/environment/india-unveils-global-solar-alliance-120-countries-paris-climate-summit|title=India Unveils Global Solar Alliance of 120 Countries at Paris Climate Summit|last=Neslen|first=Arthur|date=2015-12-04|newspaper=AlterNet|access-date=2016-08-06}} One of the hopes of the ISA is that wider deployment will reduce production and development costs, and thus facilitate increased deployment of solar technologies, including in poor and remote regions. == History == Solar PV installations in France started being substantial only from around 2008. Between 2009 and 2011 PV capacity grew almost tenfold, from a relatively low level. In its 2014 report "Global Market Outlook for Photovoltaics", the [[European Photovoltaic Industry Association]] (EPIA) not only blames the French government for a lack of support, but also criticizes it for having "hastily freeze or reduce support mechanisms" for further photovoltaic deployment.{{cite web|url=http://www.epia.org/fileadmin/user_upload/Publications/EPIA_Global_Market_Outlook_for_Photovoltaics_2014-2018_-_Medium_Res.pdf|title=Global Market Outlook for Photovoltaics 2014-2018|website=www.epia.org|publisher=EPIA - European Photovoltaic Industry Association|pages=26|format=PDF|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6QGSvAF7w?url=http://www.epia.org/fileadmin/user_upload/Publications/EPIA_Global_Market_Outlook_for_Photovoltaics_2014-2018_-_Medium_Res.pdf|archivedate=12 June 2014|accessdate=12 June 2014|url-status=dead}} The EPIA also asserts that opposition from the conventional energy sector led to a negative image of PV technology in the public opinion. The French solar association SOLER urged the French government for more support and submitted a five-point plan in Spring 2014.{{cite web|url=http://www.pv-tech.org/news/french_government_faces_calls_to_revive_domestic_pv_sector|title=French government faces calls to revive domestic PV sector|last1=Willis|first1=Ben|date=23 January 2014|website=pv-tech.org/|accessdate=16 June 2014}} Solar power in France continued growing steadily and reached a cumulative photovoltaic capacity of 6.6 GW by the end of 2015, producing 6.7 TWh of electricity during the year.{{Cite web|url=http://www.developpement-durable.gouv.fr/IMG/pdf/CS732.pdf|title=COMMISSARIAT GENERAL AU DEVELOPPEMENT DURABLE, Chiffres et Statisque no. 732 Feb 2016.|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160805231028/http://www.developpement-durable.gouv.fr/IMG/pdf/CS732.pdf|archivedate=2016-08-05}} In 2015 [[France]] was the country with the seventh largest solar PV installed capacity in the world.{{Cite web|url=http://www.iea-pvps.org/fileadmin/dam/public/report/statistics/IEA-PVPS_-__A_Snapshot_of_Global_PV_-_1992-2015_-_Final.pdf|title=Snapshot of Global Photovoltaic Markets, IEA PVPS p14.|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}} Around 903 MW of new installations were added during the year. In 2016, France was ranked 4th in the EU by installed capacity and 14th in terms of PV capacity by inhabitant at 107.3 Wp/Inhab compared to the EU average of 197.8 Wp/Inhab for the year. The country's largest completed solar park to date was the 300 MW Cestas Solar Park.{{cite web|url=http://www.actu-environnement.com/ae/news/centrale-solaire-photovoltaique-cestas-bordeaux-24900.php4#video&xtor=EREC-107|title=Titanesque ! La centrale photovoltaïque de Cestas, en Gironde|author=Baptiste Clarke|work=Actu-Environnement}} Approximately 560 MW of new installations were added during the year. In 2018, the state-owned company [[Électricité de France|EDF]] had plans to invest up to €25 billion in PV power generation, and introduce green electricity tariffs; the plan is projected to "develop 30 gigawatt of solar capacity in France between 2020 and 2035".{{cite news |url=https://www.ft.com/content/9f3ef348-12d0-11e8-8cb6-b9ccc4c4dbbb |title=EDF revenues slip as nuclear pressures bite |author=Cat Rutter Pooley |newspaper=Financial Times |date=16 February 2018 |accessdate=16 February 2018}}{{cite news |url= https://www.reuters.com/article/edf-solar/corrected-edf-says-to-develop-30-gw-of-solar-in-france-by-2035-idUSE8N1IQ02R |title= CORRECTED-EDF says to develop 30 GW of solar in France by 2035 |author= Geert De Clercq |publisher= Reuters |date= 2017-12-11 |accessdate= 2018-07-11 }} == Insolation == The [[insolation]] in France ranges from 3 sun hours/day in the north to 5 sun hours/day in the south. {{clear}} == Solar PV market by segment == {| class="wikitable" ! colspan="2" |Installed Capacity in France by class size 2017{{Cite web|url=https://www.pvp4grid.eu/wp-content/uploads/2018/12/D2.1_Existing-future-prosumer-concepts_PVP4G-1.pdf|title=EXISTING AND FUTURE PV PROSUMER CONCEPTS , pg. 18}} |- |<9 kW |15.9% |- |9–100 kW |18.6% |- |100–250 kW |13.8% |- |>250 kW |51.7% |} === Residential solar PV capacity === According to a report on behalf of the European Commission by 2020 France would have an estimated 1,484 MW of residential solar PV capacity with 458,000 residential solar PV prosumers in the country representing 1.6% of households.{{Cite web|url=https://ec.europa.eu/commission/sites/beta-political/files/study-residential-prosumers-energy-union_en.pdf|title=Study on "Residential Prosumers in the European Energy Union"}} The average size of residential solar PV systems is estimated to be 3.24 kW moving to 2030. The technical potential for residential solar PV in France is estimated at 34,810 MW. The payback time for residential Solar PV in France is 25.1 years as of 2015. Some of the advantages of small scale residential Solar include eliminating the need for extra land, keeping cost saving advantages in local communities and empowering households to become prosumers of renewable electricity and thus raising awareness of wasteful consumption habits and environmental issues through direct experience. === Large photovoltaic power stations === {{further|Photovoltaic power station|List of photovoltaic power stations}} [[File:Watts per capita France.svg|thumb|PV capacity in watt-per-capita by region in 2013 {| style="width: 100%; font-size: 0.85em" |- | valign=top | {{legend|#FFB380|border=1px solid #E5B99A|0–1 watt}} {{legend|#FF9955|border=1px solid #D99C73|1–10 watts}} {{legend|#FF7F2A|border=1px solid #CE7F4B|10–50 watts}} {{legend|#FF6600|border=1px solid #B46631|50–100 watts}} | valign=top | {{legend|#D45500|border=1px solid #8C4F26|100–200 watts}} {{legend|#AA4400|border=1px solid #3C2310|200–350 watts}} {{legend|#803300|border=1px solid #140C05|350–500 watts}} |} ]] {| class="wikitable sortable" !colspan=4|Solar Parks |- !Name!!MWp!!Location!!Notes |- |[[Cestas Solar Park]] | align=center |300 |{{coord|44|43|32|N|0|49|1|W}} | |- |[[Toul-Rosières Solar Park]] | align=center |115 |{{Coord|48|46|48|N|005|58|48|E}} | |- |[[Gabardan Solar Park]] | align=center |67.2 |{{coord|44|02|42|N|0|01|36|W}} | |- |[[Les Mées, Alpes-de-Haute-Provence|Les Mées]] Solar Park[http://phys.org/news/2011-10-france-vast-solar-panel-array.html France launches vast solar panel array] | align=center |90 |{{coord|44|00|N|6|00|E}} | Multiple sections |- |[[Crucey-Villages|Crucey]] Solar Park[http://www.edf-energies-nouvelles.com/uploads/medias/1686/pr_crucey_280912_final_eng.pdf EDF Energies Nouvelles commissions a 60 MWp solar power plant in Crucey -
